comments.commentBody: You are measuring the wrong thing.  Performance is about the performance muscles not the core.  However, it is hard to perform with persistent back pain from core imbalance.  Many sports ignore the abs and it is easy to overdevelop the back.  Even gymnastics, my previous sport, it is easy to overdevelop back and hip flexors.  A rigorous course of crunches and leg lifts using abs finally eliminated the back pain I competed with through my entire career.  I still have occasional visits to PT for back pain.  And it is always correction of ab exercises.

I have to say, I am as serious a Pats fan as there is in NC and really know & love my team - but - the article written by Andy is outstanding - he gets it better than any writer over the past 11 years. So many fans out there who are dripping with sports jealousy ("sj"), they can't think intelligently to see why this franchise is at or above the Steelers of 70's, Redskind/49ers of 80's and Cowboys of 90's - because they are doing this in the free agency era! Very difficult. Those other teams kept players for extended lengths of their repective "dynasties". NE has created a culture within it's organization that most companies wish they had within their 4 walls. Bravo to Kraft, Belichick & Brady for being the foundation of what will now perpetuate in New England for many years - winning seasons and a team that is a delight to watch!

13-3, sweep jets, SB #4 for TB, Mallet takes over for TB in 2014...

"The agency, in a nutshell, thinks there is some chance that the government will default or be delinquent on its debt payments."
Uhhh... No. The agency, in a nutshell, thinks there is some chance of the investor not recovering the money he lent to the american government. For instance, if mr. Bernanke's suggestion is followed and the Am. Gov. prints his way out of the debt, then the investor loses his money just the same, even with the US gov. technically in the clear....

OK - so democracy is just not going to work to solve national/global problems anymore - too many voices, too many problems, too many hidden agendas, too many heads in the sand.

Which choice seems more palatable? Dictator Obama, or Dictator Rove/Norquist/Perry?

If we have a double dip recession, the electability circle will expand alot like when a star becomes a red giant. When that happens, nearly everyone in the GOP field will become more than just electable. That is why Democrats must not root for the candidate they think is least electable, because their wish may haunt them for the rest of their lives. Just like their wish that the unelectable Ronald Reagan win the GOP nomination in 1980. I also remember that Bill Clinton was unelectable in 1992. In fact, the presidential election was suppose to come down to George Bush versus Ross Perot.

Please read the article. the investigation was underway BEFORE the downgrade. It would make no sense for Justice to lie about that. There would be records of when the investigation began that Congress could easily subpoena if there were doubts. This raises the terrifying possibility that a private company downgraded US debt setting off turmoil in global markets purely to derail an investigation into its activities. More terrifying is that the same company apparently was not at all afraid of compounding its prior fraud by openly taking the government of the most powerful nation on Earth. It is almost too unbelievable for words.

I don't care how it looks. If the Justice Dept. does not throw the entire book and then some at S&P now, we are truly lost. This global financial complex is rotten to the core. They are destablizing entire countries, making runs on the debt is states that are not by any means in dire fiscal condition. They fear nothing, no one. They are so sure they are too big to prosecute. Well, let's see. Sunlight is the best disinfectant. If Justice can't prosecute, they should just release the pages and pages of evidence they collected. Let the public decide.

The D.O.J. should be investigating Fannie and Freddie. Through these agencies, the government "forced" banks to make loans less than stellar. If the government was backing these loans, would not S&P rate such loans as safe?

Everyone here is commenting on the timing of the investigation, many suggesting it could be retaliation. However, thing that really can't be explained isn't the investigation of S&P, but the decision by S&P to downgrade the US. The S&P downgrade never made any sense to me. Not until I read this article:

"The people with knowledge of the investigation said it had picked up steam early this summer, well before the debt rating issue reached a high pitch in Washington."

S&P may have been looking for a way to politicize a Justice Dept investigation just as it was gathering steam. That might well explain the controversial -- and in my view, entirely baseless -- decision by S&P to downgrade the US.

http://twitter.com/jotman

If S&P is what it says it is and stands by its mortgage ratings, why worry?

If not, then... wake up and smell the coffee!

This is truly unbelievable. First of all, all the ratings agencies were complicit in those mortgage ratings, why is only S&P being singled out? Of course, it's because of the downgrade S&P gave the U.S. Not to mention the multiple investigations the SEC opened up against S&P in the aftermath of the downgrade. Meanwhile, it's business as usual on Wall Street. The only time the SEC or Justice Department will go after you is when you mess with the stock market and the ponzi scheme the U.S. runs on. Don't worry about all those high frequency traders running the markets, the lack of derivative regulation, the lack of any regulation whatsoever in fact, lets go after S&P.

Whether the downgrade was justified or not, these agencies should not be hit with political retaliation when they give out their ratings. This is straight up brass-knuckle politics, and goes to show how messing with the status quo and power brokers of the world can leave you bruised and bloody.

It's about time! Clearly they were negligent, if not complicit, in the CMO and swaps sales sham.

And by the way, more of their clients should do like Manatee County, FL and other municipalities have done: drop them as their rating agency.

Nothing like timely law enforcement.

Arsonists burn down the edifice, everybody knows who did it, but the cops don't move a finger for 3-4 years, giving the perps plenty of time to flee and hide evidence.

Thanks, "Justice" dept.
Wow so many commenters don't actually read the article before posting.  The article saids this investigation has been going on for months if not for years.

DOJ should see if Mr. McGraw, chairman of McGraw Hill, the owners of S&P, had any of his wealth being managed by Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, etc. and whether that was disclosed to all potential investors when his company S&P gave the ratings of the investment offerings sold by these banks that he would personally benefit from. That disclosure was not likely on S&P's disclosures and should really not even be allowed even with disclosure in small print no one was likely to read.

It's about time! And the other 2 (Moodys & Fitch)should be chased as well. But it's best to start with S&P because they showed themselves to be totally incompetent 2007/2008 crash with their iffy ratings. If Madoff needs a few companions to talk shop & ease the loneliness of time behind bars, then these S&P guys are it.

This is one time to say, "Guilty, before charged"!
The Feds could not even wait a month?  Have they never been schooled on how revenge is best served?

The role of rating agencies is strongly suspect. Many investors including pension funds blindly believe their assessments and commit their funds. These agencies have no humanly understandable logic to give top rating to sub-prime mortgages. They should be brought to justice.

During 1999 to 2003, I dealt with all of the ratings agencies on behalf of special servicers for Commercial Mortgage Backed Securities (CMBS) when properties encumbered by mortgages in the CMBS trusts were being sold, and the mortgages were "locked in", couldn't be repaid, so that as a result the buyers of the projects had to qualify to assume the loans and sign assumption agreements.  Uniformly, the analysts at all of the ratings agencies who I spoke with were some of the dumbest bunnies scurrying along the streets of New York.   Then, I won an appellate court case where the court ruled that a potential municipal securities issuer couldn't own certain assets they had purchased for cash and had to sell them.  Instead the headstrong manager of the municipal agency maneuvered to encumber the illegally-owned-assets by way of a Certificate of Participation (aka muni bond deal).  I actually called the man who was rating the issuance of the COPs/bonds, faxed him the Court of Appeals opinion, and he rated the debt AAA anyway.  So tell me securities industry professionals, do you their a defense of "abject stupidity" on the part of rating agencies analysts and lawyers will work in civil and criminal prosecutions?
The DOJ needs to investigate the current administration :  For economic stupidity for starters. And then for class/race baiting.

Up to this point, Obama and his administration have pursued none of the financial players responsible for the meltdown.

And now S&P is being investigated...not undeservedly so. But the timing is way late, and adds to the portrayal of Mr Obama as not only inneffective, but also amateurish.

But if the Department of Justice went after all those too big to fail gambling institutions that toyed with and destroyed the financial security of millions of Americans, then probably the re-election campaign coffers would be much emptier.

The Justice Department is going to investigate?  Excuse me, but that investigation has already taken place and the results compiled and published in "Reckless Endangerment," a book by two top NYT business writers; it has been widely read by many Americans with inquiring minds. Now it seems time to prosecute, but since some very big guns are clearly guilty, S&P among them, don't expect to see any of these people take that old perp walk any time soon... if ever.

Did we read the same article?  The DOJ began the investigation before the downgrade.  "The investigation began before Standard & Poor’s cut the United States’ AAA credit rating this month..."  So how is it that some commenting here think the administration is retaliating against S&P for the downgrade?  If anything, S&P got wind of the investigation and it may have then influenced their decision to downgrade.  Makes a little more sense, doesn't it?  Read the article people.

Please read the article, folks, before commenting. The investigation has been going on since long before there was any threat of a debt downgrade. If anyone was "retaliating," it was S&P. Hard to believe they'd be that stupid, though on the other hand...

Political retribution for debt downgrade that was more than reserved. While the rating agencies are nothing more than financial thieves and a member in good standing with the financial mafia, the current administration is just as corrupt.

Throw the bums out.

Those who would believe the DOJ could gin up an investigation of S&P in this short a period of time are hallucinating. This has undoubtedly been in the works for a long time. These cases must be developed with great care or they will come to naught. To suggest that the WH called DOJ after the recent downgrade and said sic'em defies any reasoned thought.
